description.en: Empirical rules showing how weak layers cap capability.

definition.en: Clarity Laws are empirical rules governing how operational systems behave, regardless of acknowledgment. They reveal structural constraints that determine capability limits, integration dynamics, and evolutionary potential across intelligence systems.

principles.name: You don't rise above your weakest layer
principles.description: Operational capability is constrained by the least mature layer in your system. Advanced interfaces can't compensate for fragmented data; sophisticated automations can't overcome inconsistent logic.

principles.name: Automation without architecture accelerates entropy at scale
principles.description: When processes lack architectural integrity, automation compounds problems rather than solving them, creating more exceptions than efficiencies.

principles.name: Interfaces accelerate dysfunction if upstream layers are broken
principles.description: Dashboards and tools built atop weak foundations don't just fail to solve problems; they actively reinforce dysfunction by creating false confidence.

principles.name: Feedback is not a report; it's whether the system learns
principles.description: Measurements that don't drive adaptation aren't feedbackâ€”they're noise.

principles.name: Semantic alignment is a structural advantage
principles.description: Organizations where everyone agrees on what key terms mean operate with significantly less friction than those with semantic fragmentation.
